FM..MyLT|PLB3^G:
Considerable interest lac boon shown by coveral NABB members in the use
of FM Multiplex operation,, A report by the NAEB Engineering Committee about one
year ago indicated that no such equipment was available on the market at that time0
Recently, however, the Multiplex Services Corporation, 25 Vanderbilt Ave*, Hew York
has developed and Is marketing equipment for this use. It was shown and demonstrated
at the NARTB equipment exhibit and this 1 Multicasting ” equipment is described in
this report*
By the use of multiplex equipment it is possible to use an FM transmitter
for broadcasting the regular program on the assigned frequency and at the same
time broadcast one or more other, and differing programs from the same
transmitter „ This is accomplished by super "imposing one or more FM subcarriers
on the main carrier of the FM station* A special multiplex modulator unit must be
installed at the transmitter for each multiplexed subcarrier* hi operation, the main
carrier (or regular program service) is received as before* However, it is
necessary to use a special adaptor with each receiver to ree tai ve the multiplexed
subcarrier* At present, using the main carrier channel and one multiplexed channel,
it is possible to transmit an audio frequency range of 50 - 15000 cycles per second
on each channel. If more than one multiplexed subcarrier channel is used, the
audio frequency range is limited to 50 - 8500 cyics par second*
NAEB members may be interested hi this system if they are close enough
to form a local network* In such an application the main carrier would be used for
regular broadcasting and the subcarrier used as a relay transmission link. Costs
